keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a man accused of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, was sentenced to between five and life in prison for a first-degree rape conviction, reflecting Utah’s legal approach to serious sexual offenses.
Rossi faked his death in 2020 by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to him being identified through a DNA match and later extradited after being found in Scotland.
Rossi used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, to evade capture and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
The victim testified that Rossi exploited her financially, pressured her into debt, and raped her during an engagement, which sparked the investigation.

Rossi’s attempt to escape the U.S. by faking his death and using aliases raises broader concerns about the risks posed by flight risks and the importance of DNA backlog systems in solving sexual violence cases.
The case underscores the role of public awareness and legal reforms in ensuring accountability for sexual violence, especially in cases with delayed reporting.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man accused of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, to a prison term ranging from five years to life in prison. Rossi, whose real name is Nicholas Alahverdian, was identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog. He attempted to evade justice by faking his death in 2020, with an obituary claiming he died of lymphoma, which was later disproven. Authorities tracked him to Scotland, where he was arrested while receiving treatment for COVID-19 due to distinctive tattoos linked to an Interpol notice. He was extradited to Utah in January 2024 after years of legal battles and used aliases such as Arthur Knight. Rossi maintained his innocence during the trial and failed to testify. The victim testified about financial manipulation, deception, and the traumatic rape that occurred during an engagement. The case underscores the dangers of flight risks, the importance of DNA backlog systems, and the role of international cooperation in solving crimes involving sexual violence.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
